items.title: Australian property market hits first snag in years
items.description: The red-hot Australian housing market is showing the first signs of easing since interest rates started rising back in May 2022.

items.title: Russia says 20 killed in Ukrainian strike in occupied Kherson region
items.description: It comes as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says Russia is bringing the conflict "into the new year" with a barrage of drone strikes on the country's energy infrastructure.

items.title: More than 120 business leaders call for Bondi attack royal commission
items.description: Former Reserve Bank governors and CEOs are among 125 business leaders now calling for a Commonwealth royal commission in the wake of the Bondi Beach terror attack.

items.title: Satellites to enable seamless global 5G and 6G by 2030

featured_image.name: AST SpaceMobile Launches Its Most Powerful Direct-to-Cell ...

items.description:
Satellite communication systems are poised to integrate with terrestrial mobile networks by 2030, eliminating dead zones and delivering the next generation of wireless connectivity to billions of smartphones worldwide, according to a comprehensive analysis published this week in the journal Engineering.

The article, "Evolution of Satellite Communication Systems Toward 5G/6G for 2030 and Beyond," reviews how satellites at various orbital altitudes will combine with ground-based infrastructure to form a unified 5G and 6G communications platform[1][2][3]. The International Telecommunication Union has designated 2030 as the target for deploying IMT-2030—the official designation for 6G—which aims to deliver peak speeds of 1 terabit per second, a hundredfold increase over current 5G networks[4][5].

items.title: Dozens killed in New Year's Eve fire at Swiss ski resort bar
items.description: Dozens of people are feared to have been killed and around 100 others injured after a fire tore through a crowded bar during a New Year's Eve party in a luxury ski resort town.

items.title: 'I need revenge': Sabalenka targets Kyrgios rematch
items.description: Aryna Sabalenka does not want her "Battle of the Sexes" clash with Nick Kyrgios to be the last and insists exhibitions have a vital role to play in tennis.

items.title: Banged-up Millennium Falcon the last boat to finish Sydney to Hobart
items.description: A boat named after a Star Wars spacecraft is the final entry to finish the Sydney to Hobart yacht race, after facing a range of issues at sea and extremely rough weather.

items.title: Amyl and the Sniffers singer sues photographer over fine art prints
items.description: Punk rocker Amy Taylor has filed a lawsuit against an American photographer, alleging that photos taken for a magazine photo shoot are being sold against her wishes and without her permission.

items.title: US says Ukraine did not target Putin in drone strike
items.description:
U.S. national security officials determined that Ukraine did not target Russian President Vladimir Putin or his residences in a recent drone strike, contradicting Moscow's allegations and casting doubt on claims that threaten to derail peace negotiations.

The assessment, backed by the Central Intelligence Agency, found no evidence Ukraine aimed at Putin in the alleged December 28-29 incident, according to a U.S. official familiar with the intelligence[1][2][3]. The finding was first reported by The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday[4][5].

Russia claimed on Monday that Ukraine launched 91 long-range attack drones at Putin's Valdai residence in the Novgorod region, calling it a "terrorist attack"[6][7][8]. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said all drones were intercepted and warned Moscow would revise its negotiating position[7][9][8]. However, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy swiftly dismissed the allegations as "another lie" intended to sabotage diplomatic progress[9][10].

items.title: NASA to launch Artemis II moon mission in 2026

featured_image.name: 2026 set to be the year NASA astronauts fly around the moon ...

items.description:
NASA is preparing to return astronauts to the moon's vicinity for the first time in more than half a century, while stargazers can look forward to a spectacular total lunar eclipse and the year's brightest supermoon.

The Artemis II mission is scheduled to launch no earlier than February 5, 2026, with launch windows open through the end of April, according to NASA officials[1][2][3]. The 10-day mission will send four astronauts—NASA's Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover and Christina Koch, along with Canadian Space Agency astronaut Jeremy Hansen—on a lunar flyby[4][5]. The crew will become the first people to travel beyond low-Earth orbit since Apollo 17 in December 1972[1][4]. Glover will be the first Black man, Koch the first woman, and Hansen the first non-American to venture this far from Earth[6].

items.title: Three drownings at NSW beaches in 'terrible' start to new year
items.description: A man and two women have died and two people are missing following four separate incidents on Sydney waters over the past 48 hours.

items.title: U.S. grants TSMC annual license for chip gear exports to China

featured_image.name: US revokes TSMC Nanjing VEU by 2025,…

items.description: The US Department of Commerce has issued an annual export license to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, allowing the chipmaker to continue importing American manufacturing equipment to its facility in Nanjing, China, the company announced Thursday[1][2]. The approval, granted just before a longstanding waiver system expired on December 31, marks a shift from blanket permissions to tighter, year-by-year controls[1][2].

items.title: US, Ukraine, European allies hold peace talks

featured_image.name: US held talks with Ukraine, European countries on next steps in ending Ukraine war, Witkoff says

items.description:
President Donald Trump's advisors held telephone discussions on December 31 with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy and national security advisors from the United Kingdom, France, and Germany to strategize on next steps in ending Russia's war in Ukraine, according to U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff[1][2][3].

The talks, which included U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio, Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner, and Ukraine's chief negotiator Rustem Umerov, focused on strengthening security guarantees, developing deconfliction mechanisms, and advancing a "prosperity package" for Ukraine's post-war recovery[1][2][4]. French President Emmanuel Macron announced that many European states and allies will make concrete commitments to protect Ukraine at a meeting in Paris on January 6[5][5].

"We focused on how to move the discussions forward in a practical way on behalf of @POTUS' peace process, including strengthening security guarantees and developing effective deconfliction mechanisms to help end the war and ensure it does not restart," Witkoff wrote on social media[2][4].

items.title: New York City rings in new year with famous ball drop
items.description: Cities around the world have rung in the new year in spectacular style, with fireworks lighting up famous landmarks from the London Eye to Egypt's pyramids.

items.title: Trump shares editorial blasting Putin as Ukraine talks stall

featured_image.name: Trump Shares Editorial Criticizing Putin After Talks Stall ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump on Wednesday signaled frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin by sharing a New York Post editorial that blames the Kremlin for obstructing peace negotiations in Ukraine[1][2]. The editorial, titled "Putin 'attack' bluster shows Russia is the one standing in the way of peace," was posted to Trump's Truth Social account without additional comment[3][2].

The public rebuke came hours before Putin delivered his annual New Year's address vowing victory in Ukraine, telling troops "we believe in you and our victory"[4][5]. The dueling messages highlighted the difficulties facing U.S.-led efforts to broker an end to the nearly four-year conflict, despite Trump's recent optimism that a deal may be within reach.

items.title: China installs world's most powerful hypergravity centrifuge
items.description:
China has taken the lead in hypergravity research with the arrival of CHIEF1900, a centrifuge capable of generating gravitational forces 1,900 times stronger than Earth's gravity. Developed by Shanghai Electric Nuclear Power Group, the machine was delivered to Zhejiang University on December 22 and is currently being installed at the university's underground research facility in Hangzhou[1][2].

Once operational, CHIEF1900 will surpass all existing hypergravity centrifuges worldwide, including its predecessor CHIEF1300, which began operations in September with a capacity of 1,300 gravity-tonnes[1][3]. The previous world record was held by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers facility in Vicksburg, Mississippi, with a capacity of approximately 1,200 gravity-tonnes[1][4].

items.title: Planning to travel overseas in 2026? These law changes might affect you
items.description: From currency changes to cleaner toilets, here's what is changing around the world in the new year.

items.title: Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 resumes in Indian Ocean

featured_image.name: HUGIN AUV to Ocean Infinity - Kongsberg Maritime

items.description:
A search vessel equipped with advanced underwater robots arrived in the Indian Ocean on Wednesday to resume the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, marking the first major effort in years to solve one of aviation's most enduring mysteries[1][2][3].

Malaysia's Transport Ministry confirmed that the Armada 86 05 reached a designated search area with two autonomous underwater vehicles, reviving hopes of finally locating the Boeing 777 that vanished with 239 people on board on March 8, 2014[1][2][4]. The ministry did not disclose the exact location of the search zone, but stated the vessel prepared for operations at Fremantle Port in Western Australia[1][2].

items.title: Nvidia in talks to acquire AI21 Labs for up to $3B

featured_image.name: In this photo illustration, a NVIDIA logo is seen displayed...

items.description:
Nvidia is positioning itself to capitalize on surging AI demand through two major transactions announced this week: a planned $14 billion chip purchase from ByteDance and the potential acquisition of Israeli AI startup AI21 Labs for up to $3 billion.

The dual deals underscore the chipmaker's aggressive expansion strategy as competition intensifies in artificial intelligence infrastructure, though both transactions face regulatory hurdles that could determine their ultimate success.

items.title: Big Four firms deploy thousands of AI agents in 2025

featured_image.name: Big Four bet on AI agents that can do all the work and 'liberate' staff

items.description:
As 2025 draws to a close, artificial intelligence has fundamentally reshaped professional services and management roles, with the workforce racing to adapt through intensive reskilling as organizations prepare for even deeper transformation in 2026.

The Big Four professional services firms—Deloitte, EY, PwC, and KPMG—have deployed thousands of AI agents this year, setting a blueprint for how businesses worldwide will operate[1][2][3]. EY advanced 1,000 AI agents into development or production in 2025, with plans to scale to 100,000 by 2028[3][4]. PwC deployed 25,000 intelligent agents across client operations[4], while Deloitte's Zora AI platform reduced finance team costs by 25% and increased productivity by 40%[5][6].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
